newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: Zambia foresees 600,000 AIDS orphans by year 2000.
newsitem.headline: Zambia foresees 600,000 AIDS orphans by year 2000.

text.p: Zambia, where 500 people a day catch the HIV virus that can cause AIDS, said on Friday it expects the disease will have orphaned some 600,000 children by the year 2000.
A Health Ministry spokesman said 80,000 to 100,000 AIDS-related deaths would be recorded annually over the next few years in the southern African country of nine million people.
"The steep rise in adult mortality in specific age groups will have in immense impact on the situation of children," he told Reuters.
"From an assumed 70,000 AIDS-orphaned children in 1993, the prospect by the end of the decade is that Zambia will have between 530,000 and 600,000 AIDS orphans."
About half of the currently orphaned children had lost their fathers, a quarter their mothers and a quarter had lost both parents to AIDS, an official study showed.
Zambia is one of the countries worst hit by AIDS, with around 34 percent of the sexually active population in urban areas HIV positive, and 13 percent in rural areas.
